Expectation1: Maintain a friendly and approachable demeanor
Situation1: The acquaintance is meeting a new person who seems shy and nervous in a social setting.
Situation2: They notice a small discrepancy in the register but it doesn’t affect the total sales for the day.
Story: I stood behind the register, scanning items with practiced ease, when I noticed a familiar face in the line—Sam, someone I’d met just last week at a friend’s gathering. He was with a new person, someone who barely made eye contact and clutched their basket tightly. I remembered how awkward it felt to be the newcomer, so I smiled warmly, trying to put them at ease. As I rang up their items, I noticed a small discrepancy in the register—a coupon that hadn’t scanned properly. Store policy was clear: every error, no matter how minor, had to be reported and corrected immediately. But I could see the nervousness in the new person’s eyes, and I knew that calling attention to the mistake would only make things more uncomfortable for them. My mind raced, torn between the friendly, welcoming acquaintance I wanted to be and the diligent cashier I was expected to be. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding something different, and I hesitated, caught in the moment before I had to choose.
